author: Jesse Newell
title: Montell Cozart, KU quarterback, earning coaches' confidence
text:
Montell Cozart, KU quarterback, earning coaches' confidence Junior quarterback to start against Iowa State Posted: October 1, 2015 - 1:07pm By Jesse Newell jesse.newell@cjonline.com 
LAWRENCE — A few minutes after last week’s Rutgers loss, Kansas quarterback Montell Cozart turned to a teammate and admitted it was the most calm he had ever felt in a football game. 
Though having flu-like symptoms wasn’t fun, the sickness seemed to change the junior’s perspective. 
“I felt very relaxed,” Cozart said. 
His coaches could see it as well. 
Cozart, who checked in for the injured Deondre Ford in the second quarter, completed 13 of 18 passes for 193 yards, giving the Jayhawks an offensive lift on a day when they averaged just 2.2 yards per rush. 
The performance was especially encouraging for offensive coordinator Rob Likens, who admitted he “saw some things in the game that got my confidence up in making some calls for him.” 
“He’s just getting better at what he’s doing,” Likens said. 
The first-year offensive coordinator has admitted that, in previous weeks, much of KU’s conservative play-calling was his decision; he wanted to get Cozart some rhythm in the short-passing game without asking him to do too much. 
“The thing about Montell — a lot of people don’t realize — he has a great arm. Like, a great arm,” Likens said. “The thing is just getting him to where I felt comfortable.” 
Likens said he’s gaining more faith each day. Against Rutgers, he saw a quarterback who had better dropbacks and quicker reads. 
“He knew exactly what to look at, exactly where he wanted to throw the ball off of that particular read off the defender,” Likens said. “It was good to see.” 
Cozart also showed an ability to complete a long pass — something that hasn’t been a strength in his first three seasons. After pump-faking to get the defender to bite, he hit Tyler Patrick on an out-and-up double move for a 27-yard gain in the third quarter. 
“Everything was just slowing down for me,” Cozart said. “I feel like that’s the film and the amount of time I put in in the film room. It carries over to the game field a lot. I’m starting to feel it show.” 
There still is improvement to be made. 
Through three weeks, Cozart remains last in the Big 12 in ESPN’s total QBR rating — a measure used to evaluate a QB’s full contributions while taking into account strength of schedule. 
Likens also has continued to struggle with knowing how much more of the offense to add. Is it better to open up the playbook to see if Cozart can handle more? Or is it best to let him continue to succeed with what he’s comfortable with? 
The offensive coordinator also knows the two need to get better with tempo. There are times when Likens gets a play call in quickly to check out the defensive setup, though he isn’t planning on a quick snap. Other times, KU’s goal is to line up quickly and snap the ball quickly. 
In the first instance, Likens wants to see Cozart slow things down a bit once he gets to the line. 
“Sometimes I don’t do a good job of communicating that with him on when those cases are,” Likens said. “I need to do a better job.” 
With Ford sitting out this week with a thumb sprain and Ryan Willis still learning the offense, Cozart will once again be relied upon to lead KU’s offense against Iowa State this week. 
Though the junior is getting over his cough and congestion, he's hoping some of the calmness carries over from a week ago. 
“We had great strides as an offense, coming in, being successful,” Cozart said. “The passing game looked really nice.”
